title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check for child care providers under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates criminal background checks for child care staff, family child care providers, and adults living in a family child care provider's home. Checks include searches of national and state criminal registries, the National Sex Offender Registry, and state-based abuse and neglect databases. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires criminal background checks for child care providers, including searches of national and state registries, the National Sex Offender Registry, and state abuse and neglect databases. Providers are ineligible for funds if a felony conviction for certain offenses is found during the background check. The "Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" mandates criminal background checks for child care providers, including checking for controlled substance offenses within 5 years prior to the background check submission. Providers must request a State and national criminal background check through the designated State agency every 5 years. The Act mandates criminal background checks for child care providers every 5 years, including controlled substance offenses within 5 years prior to submission. Only one request for a State and national criminal background check is required for each provider. The Act requires criminal background checks for child care providers every 5 years. Results must be provided within 10 business days of the request. States must ensure the accuracy of the information in the background check. The background check must be accurate and complete by obtaining dispositions of arrests, correcting inaccurate information, completing incomplete entries, and taking steps to improve accuracy. Appeals can be made to the State agency within 30 days of receiving the results. State must determine individual's eligibility, provide specific appeal findings, make changes to inaccurate records, and report changes. States can collect one fee per background check from child care providers, not exceeding $36. States must implement background check procedures within a time limit. State compliance with the Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 requires implementation within 3 years, with a possible 2-year extension for states making good faith efforts. Definitions include an adult as someone 18 years or older and a child care provider as a licensed entity providing regular compensated child care services. The term 'child care staff member' refers to an individual who provides child care services for compensation on a regular basis, excluding those related to the children in their care. A 'family child care provider' is an individual who provides child care services for fewer than 24 hours per day in a private residence, not related to all the children in their care, and is licensed, regulated, or registered under State law. State law or receives funds under this subchapter. Authorization of Appropriations To Conduct Criminal Background Checks: Appropriations authorized for administrative costs of State and national criminal background checks.
